newsitem.title: TURKEY: TURK CB HEAD SEES '97 INFLATION AT AROUND 80 PCT.
newsitem.headline: TURK CB HEAD SEES '97 INFLATION AT AROUND 80 PCT.

text.p: Turkey's central bank governor Gazi Ercel said wholesale inflation rate for end-1997 was expected to stand at around 80 percent this year.
"Our studies on the wholesale inflation shows that the end-year inflation this year will be above the target of 70 percent," he was quoted as saying by the liberal daily Yeni Yuzyil on Tuesday.
"It may be 78 to 79 percent, or even slightly higher than 80 percent," he said.
The government's year-on-year wholesale inflation target was 57.5 percent for 1997, but Ercel had previously said the bank was basing its plans on a 70-percent inflation rate expectation for 1997.
Ercel said slow progress in privatisation, lack of an accord with the International Monetary Fund and failure to realise some planed revenues would keep inflation higher.
Turkey's year-on-year wholesale inflation rate was 72.8 percent in April, compared to 84.9 percent at end-1996.
Turkey is working on a medium-term stability plan to lower the hyperinflation rate to below 10 percent over three years.

"We have said the (70-percent) rate could be achieved if the government succeeds in four areas -- an accord with the IMF (International Monetary Fund), speedy privatisations, external and domestic borrowing and keeping primary budget surplus at 1996 levels," he said.
"Now we see that only in the area of borrowing we do not have problems, but the other areas have not seen any improvements," he said.
"It has become clearer that the primary budget surplus for 1997 will be less than its level last year," he said.
Turkey's primary budget surplus, excluding interest payments, was 279,661 trillion lira at end-1996, compared to the budget deficit of 1,217 trillion lira for last year.
